title: NDIS termination payments AWOL in Senate estimates
text:
Returning to the administration of the National Disability Insurance Agency. At Thursday’s Senate estimates hearings of the community affairs committee, Labor senator Carol Brown wanted “information on the termination payments for the former CEO and others who left at the same time or very soon after”.

You might recall that NDIA chief executive Rob de Luca resigned in April. Three of his seven direct reports – Michael Francis, Antonia Albanese and Anthony Vella – subsequently did the same. Much to the delight of NDIA-preferred head hunter Russell Reynolds!

NDIA head of people Hamish Aikman (paid $481,281 in FY19) told the senator from Tasmania “there have been no termination payments related to recent senior executives who have departed the agency.”

Aikman’s unequivocal statement jars somewhat with page 134 of the NDIA’s 2018-19 annual report, released on October 16, which sets out the $245,818 “termination benefits” paid to one senior executive on a salary of $574,219 and another termination payment of $276,301 paid to another senior executive on a salary of $505,524.

Explanatory notes reveal the duo were not key management personnel (despite being paid more than any of the CEO’s direct reports), and may even have been contractors or consultants. Nevertheless, the page is headed “senior executives” and the table is entitled “Information about remuneration for senior executives in 2018-19”, so surely should have been captured by Aikman’s answer to Senator Brown’s question.
description: What the NDIA told Senate Estimates about executive termination payments contradicts the contents of its own recent annual report.
